title: Coronation Street: Katie McGlynn says Sinead's death impacted health
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Coronation Street actress Katie McGlynn has bravely admitted that filming her character Sinead Tinker’s death has affected her own mental health. Upcoming episodes of the ITV soap will see Sinead pass away after battling cervical cancer, with her final scenes due to air on Friday 25 October.

Speaking to the Loose Women panel about the heart-wrenching storyline, Katie opened up and said: ‘I kind of underestimated the effects that it’s had on my mental health.

‘I’ve only just noticed it, walking away from it and filming, that part of me is breathing Sinead and it’s bizarre.

‘I’ve started doing a fitness thing to safeguard myself and that’s really helping me mentally.’

She continued: ‘I sound silly saying it but I believe Sinead is real. I played her for six-and-a-half years. Me and Corrie created this character and I feel like she’s my friend.

Sinead passes away from cancer this week in Coronation Street (Picture: ITV)

‘Watching her die was just awful, but it’s raising awareness and I just hope that we are doing that.’

Sinead’s world came crashing down on her wedding day, when her auntie Beth (Lisa George) discovered a lump in her neck.

The following day, Sinead and husband Daniel (Rob Mallard) went to the doctors to get the lump checked out and they were left devastated to discover that the young mum’s cancer had spread to her lymph nodes and her liver, meaning she only had only months left to live.

Katie added that she asked Coronation Street bosses to lose Sinead to cancer.

‘I protested for her to die,’ she said. I just thought if I’m doing this storyline, I want to do it properly.

‘I love this storyline because it covers so many issues. I just wanted to highlight the fact people are dying of cancer.’

Loose Women airs weekdays at 12.30pm on ITV.
